description:
A competitive or cooperative, dice rolling, Zombie survival experience.
In the game, each player rolls dice to acquire different resources. These resources are used to build and maintain a group of survivors who are working to eliminate the Zombie horde while trying to survive. Each roll of the dice presents difficult choices as players must decide which of these valuable resources they will keep, spend, or chance in order to best equip their survivors!

As the game begins players take turns rolling dice. Players must work to feed their survivors, buy items such as weapons, or special skills that allow players to manipulate their dice rolls to best benefit their survivors. Players will work their way through Town, battling Zombies and gaining Victory Points for each Zombie eliminated and each survivor that remains alive. But players must beware of opponents who can draw Zombies to their location as they try to move in and steal Victory Points and other valuable rewards that are specific to each location in Town. The pace is frantic, the Zombies are hungry and survivors can easily turn on one another!

Can you survive?

Creekos: The Card Game is a trick-taking card game with a customized deck that pits two partnerships of two players against one another, first in an auction to determine the power of their cards, then in the card play itself.

At the start of the game two auctions take place, one for the number scale – that is, which value on the cards they hold will be used by the partnership – and a second for the trump color. After this, the players then compete in a trick-taking game that uses customized cards in different categories that relate to one another; in the packet "Hercules' Labors", for example, the categories are Events, Gods, People, Creatures, Lifeless. For each trick, players lay one card in the center of the table – with some cards having special abilities that activate thunderbolts or block other cards – and the most powerful card wins the trick. Once all the tricks are finished, players tally their points (subtracting however many points they bid at the start of the game), and the partnership with the high score wins.

Creekos: The Card Game can also be played by only two players, with each player competing on her own.

Object of the game is to be â€‹â€‹the first to go home with the full pie, the party favors, sandwiches, drinks and masks.

Setup: The players put up their houses on the corner of the game and choos the characters.
In his turn player spins the wheel. Either the arrow indicates a number to advance his charakter to field with something he doesn't have (party favors, sandwich, drink, masks) and he takes it.
If the arrow indicates "pie" in which case the player chooses a pie face down and shows it to everyone. if the share belongs to his pie he keeps it.

When a player has all the elements of pie he returns to home. First player to reach his house is the winner

2 Player game with fantasy theme that combines chess with worker placement.  Minions of 8 types are used as both chess pieces, some with unique moves, and also as workers. Each round players take turns placing their minions into the 16 available Tower Chambers. Each chamber holds a distinct Mage that grants a special power, such as adding a minion to the board or moving a specific type of minion on the board. Players then take turns removing their minions from the tower to activate these powers. 12 chaos mages are available to mix things up. Win by capturing your opponents greater minions or by wiping him off the board.

This is, at first glance, a puzzle but it was always intended to be a game when two want to play.

Inside are 48 plastic shapes and two trays. The puzzle element is that one set of these plastic shapes, 24 in all, must be placed into the tray in such a way that they all fit.

The game is why there are two trays and 48 pieces. Each player has a tray and 24 pieces and it is a race against time to complete the problem the fastest. That player wins.

The box promises that there are 48 puzzles to solve so that should keep a pair of solvers pleased.

Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #13.

Seinan Senso is a campaign level wargame of the Satsuma Rebellion (1877).
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satsuma_Rebellion
Designer's note writes that the game was designed with reference to basic engine of Paths of Glory and deck building concept from Dominion.

Players control either imperial Japanese Army or Rebels of Satsuma Domain. Players manage military operation and resources represented by the card.

The winner is determined by the collapse of morale. Morale will be reduced by the difference of the holding number of important spaces. Satsuma Domain player will also win that morale will not collapse until the final turn.

A traditional card game where the aim of the game is to score the minimum score possible over 11 rounds of play.

using 2 standard decks of cards shuffled together, each player is dealt a number of cards depending on the round, starting with 3 cards, then 4, 5, 6 etc until the players have 13 cards in hand for the final round.

Players attempt to "go out" by playing their cards out of their hand following the rules for each round, all other players add up the scores of their cards in hand in a running total. After 11 rounds, the player with the lowest score wins. As an extra, you can score individual points for who went out each round as a bonus competition.

Cards are scored based on their number, with face cards counting as 10 points, and aces as 25

Aces are wild cards, additionally, for each round, the card matching the number of cards in hand for that round (so, 3 in the first round, then 4, 5, 6 etc) is also wild (up to J, Q, K)

Jokers can be used additionally as wild cards, and also score 25 points if left in hand when someone goes out

On a player turn, they may draw a card from the face down draw pile, or lay any number of allowed hands to the table
When a player goes out, all other players have one final chance to play any cards from hand that they can before assessing the score of cards left in hand.

Players play their own melds to the table in front of them and can extend those in any combination as part of playing hands to the table (usually this is done as a final turn to shed cards in hand). E.g. in the round of 9 cards, if you'd earlier played a 3 of a kind and a run of 3, you could later on play another 3 of a kind to finish, OR you could for example put 1 card on the 3 of a kind to make it a 4 of a kind, and another 2 cards on the run to make it a 5 card run.

The rules for playing cards out of hand are as follows:

Round, Cards in hand to start, wild cards, allowed plays
1,3,A+3+(Joker), 3 of a kind (3K), or 3 card run flush (3R)
2,4,A+4+(Joker), 4K or 4R
3,5,A+5+(Joker), 5K or 5R
4,6,A+6+(Joker), 6K or 6R or mix of 3R, 3K
5,7,A+7+(Joker), 7K or 7R, or a mix of 3R,3K,4R,4K
6,8,A+8+(Joker), 8K or 8R, or a mix of 3,4,5 card run or set
7,9,A+9+(Joker), 9K or 9R, or a mix of 3,4,5,6 card run or set
8,10,A+10+(Joker), 10K or 10R, or mix of 3,4,5,6,7 card hands
9,11,A+J+(Joker), 11K or 11R, or mix of 3,4,5,6,7,8 card hands
10,12,A+Q+(Joker), 10K or 10R, or mix of 3,4,5,6,7,9 card hands
11,13,A+K+(Joker), 10K or 10R, or mix of 3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10 card hands

Objective: Know correct answers on questions out of the former GDR
 - acting by turn - 
A small trivia game about GDR; with 100 questions and answers. The game itself is like a notebook (with spiral binding). Each page contains 2 questions and 4 answers, the back side contains the correct answers with additional information.
Questions like: What is a 'Gummifuffziger'? How many disticts did GDR possess?

Challenge your family to games based on the hit ITV gameshow The Cube . The show's nail-biting format has been cleverly downsized for this fun family game that retains all the best elements of the series. There are seven rounds of physical and electronic challenges to complete and players have just nine lives to use up before being booted out of the game. There are options to do a Trial Run or Simplify the challenges, just like in the show, and with 50 different games included, The Cube Game is sure to keep the whole family entertained. Designed for two to six players aged eight and up, the The Cube Game is great for fans of the TV show but just as fun for those who are new to the format. Features: Family game based on the ITV gameshow Complete seven rounds of games to win 50 different games to complete Use your nine lives, Trial Run and Simplify tokens For 2 to 6 players, aged 8 and up

You're about to embark on the greatest adventure of your life.  You will have the chance to become one of six of the most unbelievable characters you will ever meet.  You become the owner of a highly technical fleet of trucks, with a dealer network worldwide.  Now you will find out if you have what it takes to be a real..."Gear Jammer".  A gear jammer is a trucker/owner that is prepared to take the chance....challenge and risk to become the most successful on the board game of...Gear Jammers!

Objective:  To see who can run the most successful trucking business...based on a combination of companies owned, trucks on the road and cash on hand.  To do this, you will want to buy all the trucks you can buy, invest in companies that are going places, and hope you won't get stuck with too many accidents, losses or heavy costs.  
What makes Gear Jammers really fun are all the chances you  take in hopes of collecting some profits.  You may run into a truck stop that means you miss a couple of turns!  We say "Go for the profits anyway!".  If you own a fleet of trucks (and the value cards in your favour) you could be the ultimate winner of the game.  But don't count on a thing until the timer goes off.  Just when you think you've got the game in the bag, your old trucking buddy may land on a "Price and Profit!" card - and turn the whole game around.

Start your engines....roll out your trucks and begin driving on the highway to success....if you dare!

A desktop bowling set. Wooden base and pins, with a wooden ramp for launching the metal bowling ball which can be pivoted to aim shots. The base has a metal backstop. Scoring and pin setup must be done manually for each frame.

The playing-field of Sqez is a rectilinear array of dots, of any convenient size — but arrays of less than 8 x 8 are too small, and exceptionally large fields may prolong the game needlessly, unless there are many players. The easiest way to make the arrays is to type up rows of full-stops on a typewriter; but it's just possible that somewhere or other you can buy dotted paper (wallpaper?), and it wouldn't be hard to get used to playing on small-squared graph paper, counting each inter¬section as a 'dot'. But I leave this to your ingenuity.
Each player in Sqez must complete a rectangle (oblong or square) by drawing a line through the dots. The line drawn must not anywhere duplicate an already placed line, though it may cross another line, or meet it at one end; and the rectangle drawn must enclose at least one 'free' dot — a free dot being defined as a dot that has no line passing through it or originating at it. The last player to complete a legal move is the winner.
Those are the entire rules, except to say that a player who places a line which he cannot (owing to miscalculation) use to make a legal move (by completing a rectangle as defined) forfeits the game.

Ausgerechnet Köln uses the same game play as the other Ausgerechnet! titles: Players deal three piles of 15 location cards from a deck of roughly 200 cards (naming locations related to Cologne for this edition), then place an interlude card between each set of piles to make a deck of 45 cards. One location card is placed on the direction board, which has arrows pointing north, south, east and west.

On a turn, a player draws a location card – keeping the latitude and longitude on the back of the card secret from all players – then places the card next to the direction board, indicating how she thinks this location relates to the starting one. Is 'Nippes' west or east of Bonn? Why sure, so place it by the west arrow. Location cards can be placed between cards already on the board.

After each location card is placed, any player can challenge the positioning of that card. That player reveals the back of the most recently placed card as well as one adjacent card. If the challenge was correct – and the card placed wrongly – the challenger wins a point chip from the placer and the card is removed; otherwise the challenger hands over a chip to that person.

After 15 cards are placed, the interlude card signals an interim scoring in which all players secretly guess how many cards have been placed correctly. Guess correctly, and you score two chips; if no one is spot on, the closest guesser wins a chip.

After three rounds and the final interlude scoring, the player with the most chips wins.

In Lands Unknown you control a group of bold adventurers who embark on a journey into an unexplored continent. They will have to plan their advance carefully and use the terrain to their advantage if they are to best rivaling groups for control of the continent.

Each turn, a player plays a land card onto one of the coastline roads already started, marks it (if necessary), then uses the power shown on that (drawing new cards, swapping hands with an opponent, moving tokens, destroying cards or tokens, and so on). At the end of the game, players score points for their explorer tokens on the roads, and the player with the most points wins.

The board is wooden (made of exotic hardwood), into which there are 21 half-inch diameter holes. Basically the positional shape of the holes is a five times five grid with corners removed:


5 ooo
4ooooo
3ooooo
2ooooo
1 ooo
 ABCDE


The dark player has seven dark shafted game pieces to control. The light player has seven light shafted game pieces to control. Each game piece is formed as a stick which will fit nicely into any of the holes. Each piece has coloured caps at the end in six combinations:

1.) yellow / orange
2.) orange / red
3.) red / purple
4.) purple / blue
5.) blue / green
6.) green / yellow

Game rules give the hint that these form a circle of colours. This information might help and can be used to find logical game strategies here.

The seventh piece being special is

7.) white / black

Colour white is used being a 'wild' (joker). It can be used as a legal replacement for any colour mentioned before.
Black is basically a blocker not representing any colour.

Players take alternating turns. When a game piece is placed in a hole one of the coloured end caps is obviously not visible anymore. Placing a game piece the non visible colour must be announced loudly and clearly enough to the opponent while setting the piece.

On his first turn a player must place one of his pieces into any free hole. After the first turn a turn consists of one of the following actions:

1.) Play another own offboard piece into another free hole, or
2.) Turn any one of your already played pieces upside down in the same hole (announcing the non visible colour towards the opponent clearly and loudly), or
3.) Move any one of your played pieces to another hole (but not turning it upside down)

The object is to get three of the same colour in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally) and the first player to do so wins. Since each player's set contains only two caps of each colour (as listed above), at least one of the three-in-a-row might has to be an opponent's piece.

The 'wild' game piece can only be played as soon as all other six pieces are already set before. This way you can build and win creating a three-in-a-row using own and/or opponent's white game piece as well. The black colour can not be used in a three-in-a-row constellation since it is used as a blocking piece only.

In general each player can only move game pieces with a shaft of own colour. But any game piece can be used to form the three-in-a-row to win.

Initially you draw by lot who goes first. In consecutive rounds the previous loser takes the first turn.

You might find similarities in game play like in Quarto (published in 1991, using opponent's pieces as well to form the winning row) and Memory (published in 1959, remembering the hidden colours is definitively helpful).

In contrast to Tau the newer Calypso does not include the aspect of a Memory game any longer. The colour which is not visible in Tau (and has to be announced each time) is still visible in Calypso due to the other construction of the game pieces.

High noon.

The dirt crunches underneath your boots.

Sweat drips slowly down your brow.

Your fingers twitch as you reach for your gun.

A split second later your opponent lies on the ground, lifeless.

You advance to the final round of the Dodgecity Gunfight contest.

Welcome to Wild Guns! The first gunslinger card game for two or more players.

Out smart, out shoot and out play your opponent in this fast-paced, high action card game.

Check out this game review from Father Geek!

Playing Wild Guns:
Each player acts as a Wild West Gunslinger, with a Gunslinger character card placed face up in front of him, each with unique skills and abilities.

The game play of Wild Guns is quite simple. Each player has a hand of Gun cards and Run cards. In a two player game each player starts with six Gun cards and six Run cards. During the game the players place one Gun card and one Run card facedown in front of him. The other player does the same. When both players have their cards facedown on the table the player with First Shot reveals his Gun card, while is opponent reveals his Run card. Then compare the cards to ensure a shot can be made. If player A reveals a Head Shot Gun Card and Player B Reveals a Crouch Run Card - the attack from player A cannot be made, the Run card avoids his shot. The play proceeds to player B as he reveals his Gun card to compare to player A's Run card. If player B reveals a Chest Shot Gun Card and player A reveals a Jump Run Card, he jumps into the shot! Player B gets to make a shot and rolls the dice, as indicated on the Gun card.

After rolling he compares the numbers rolled his Gunslinger card and dishes out the damage to player A!

Play continues until one or both Gunslingers are dead, with zero health left! The goal of Wild Guns is to be the last Gunslinger standing.

Looking for a party game? Wild Guns is a great party game and can play with up to ten players. Watch out, this is when the bullets fly and the Gunslingers drop dead!

Magnum Opus is a deck-building game in which each player is an Alchemist trying to be the first and only scientist to complete their life's great work by successfully fabricating the ultimate alchemical substance– the Philosophers' Stone.

Unlike most victory point-oriented deck-building games, Magnum Opus is goal-oriented and plays more like a traditional card game but with a deck-building twist. Players collect different alchemical ingredients, called reagents, over the course of the game and combine them in a series of experiments in order to discover the mysteries of the Philosophers' Stone. The Discovery Matrix is where all of these experiments are conducted and the random selection and placement of Research and Discovery cards in the matrix insures that no two games are ever the same.

Earn the gold you need to purchase your reagents, gain experience from your failures and knowledge from your successes, transmute the physical and mystical elements into the Philosopher's Stone and you will go down in history for your Magnum Opus.

Isle of Eldermoor Chess is a large board chess variant.

It is played on a larger 10X10 board to allow more pieces, and then borrowed the idea of the Citadel corner from Omega Chess, an idea quickly expanded to an area of seven additional squares on each corner, leaving the board with a more castle-like appearance.

The game also uses the 'river' idea in the centre from Xiangqi, as well as an inner King's sanctum area,

The first goal of Isle of Eldermoor was to toss out the traditional Western Chess game. There are great variants such as Omega Chess, Opulent Chess, and Grand Chess which take the traditional game and add to it with a few new pieces. It's been done.

So only the King was transfered to Eldermoor.

The rest of the army array reflects more of a fantasy Medieval army, so Paladins, Cavaliers, Yeomen, Soldiers, Archers etc are used.

As an ode to long nights of Dungeons & Dragons over the years a fantasy element with Wizards, Griffins and Dragons are also part of the game

With an all new piece array, I needed different movement patterns, well different from Western Chess at least. There are so many variant pieces almost every conceivable movement pattern has been done before in one variant or another.

The resulting movements draw on Western Chess, Xiangqi, Shogi and related variants.

The game has three win conditions;

The game is won by checkmating the opposition king.

or

If a player loses both Wizards the morale of their army is broken and they lose the game.

or

You win by occupying both opponent's wizard towers, and holding them for one full turn.

The year is 2151, and the demand for pizza has never been greater.

As a hungry galaxy clamors for thin-crusted Italian delicacies, the little-understood, physics-defying Two Dimensional Drive has been employed to meet the need. By collapsing three-dimensional space down to a two-dimensional matrix, the 2D Drive makes it possible to cross vast distances in seconds. The catch? 2D ships can transport only flat cargo – which makes them perfect for pizza and not much else. (Possible caveat: Cosmic Pancakes.)

In this strange future, a daring pizza pioneer such as yourself can become rich beyond your wildest dreams – but only if you're willing to take on the risks of interstellar, two-dimensional flight. Perhaps the greatest challenge: Mastering the mind-bending reality that is two-dimensional space. Luckily for you, your ship has a tutorial mode.

Cosmic Pizza is a spatial reasoning game for 2-4 players in which players must master an ever-increasing array of dizzying maneuvers; it also boasts variable difficulty levels. If you're a hardcore puzzle fan, you can take on Space Crazy mode, while your kids zip along in the lighter Junior mode.

"Clash in the South Pacific" is an operational level board wargame for Battle of the Santa Cruz Island. Players control either the aircraft carrier fleet of Imperial Japanese Navy or United States Navy. Players manage fleet movement, search for the enemy, and aircraft operation. The basic design is similar to Task Force: Carrier Battles in the Pacific.

Winner is determined by victory points based on damage given to only opponent aircraft carrier.

This game was designed for wargame beginners.

Game scale: 75 km per hex, 90 minutesã€€per turn, 1 ship, 2 Destroyers or 9 Planes per unit.

"Auf Spurensuche am Limes" is a board game with an accompanying book with 48 pages of background information.

The game board shows a excavation site with zones of different depth. At the start of the game, findings and discoveries (tiles connected to one colour) are distributed on the site, face up. In a next step, all findings are covered with the dust of time - terrain tiles on top of them, thus creating multiple layers of tiles. Only after this, colours are assigned to the players - hopefully thy remember some of "their" findings.

Each player plays a team of archaeologists trying to excavate in particular those findings which match his own research assignment (colour). In trying to achieve that, however, fragments of roman documents might be discovered, earning the player additional points.

At a player's turn, he performs each of 4 actions:
- Move his expedition manager 1 - 3 spaces around the border of the site (to more promising sectors). His position determines the spaces of the site which can be reached by archeologists (neutral colour).
- Now the player has 5 movement points to move one or more neutral archeologists, either to the sector determined by his own expedition manager or to some bad position for the opponents.
- The 3rd action the site is explored. Two terrain tiles with archeologists on them are lifted and the things nderneath are now visible. They are (mostly) not directly available.
- Finally, the player can perform an excavation. To get the several findings visible, you need to place one or more archeologists around the space, depending on the depth of the zone.

Findings of your own colour are directly put into the museum, more worthy findings are replacing ones with lesser value.
Findings of an opponent`s colour are not that easily excavated. You need allocated points or some dice luck to get them.

Since mostly a finding is not discovered and excavated in the same turn, players have to be careful not to discover findings, which can be easily "grabbed" by their opponents.

The game ends when one player manages to excavate all of his assigned findings (winner of the game). If nobody manages to do so, the  game ends, when a player reaches the end of the "expedition track", where successful excavations and discoveries are registered, and the player with the most allocated points wins the game.

The advanced game offers fences to make it harder for opponents to excavates findings discovered by other players.

"The Battle of the Bulge" is an operational level wargame for  Ardennes Offensive. There are other games of the same name, but this one is a unique game that is designed for the wargame beginner

Players will control either German Army or Allied Army. Players manage movement and combat by basic hex and counter mechanism.
The game winner is determined by control of the important cities and exit to the map.

Game scale: 6km per hex, 1 day per turn, a division per unit

First published with Tanks and Tenka fubu in one box titled "Simulation games for beginner #1".
Republished as Command Magazine Japan #120 in 2014.

Similar to Richesses de France.
Oise is a department in the north of France.

The goal of the game is to complete a circuit in the department  faster than your opponents by traveling from city to city. This is done either by foot, bicycle, or car. Money can be earned (to buy a bicycle or car) or lost during the game.

In his turn, the player moves one space or two space with bicycle or 4 spaces with his car following different routes. Its purpose is to visit every city in any order.
Every time you stop on a region that is not named, draw a card. That brings You some good or bad news.

Player who visits all regions on game board and returns to the space he started first is the winner.

TV related game based on one of Britain's favourite shows. Essentially, contestants took part in various games and skills (mainly for their comedy value) and the game captures that flavour. Accrue points and "points mean prizes" as Bruce Forsyth (pictured on the box) famously once said. Catchphrases were Bruce's speciality and he is the originator of the most famous ones.

Browsers might know the famous Beat the Clock television show on both sides of the Atlantic and this has a certain element of that show in its style.

To object of the game is to get 3 of Your 4 pawns to the end in the order that appears on one of your cards.

Each player will try to move the pawns in the order of the "trifecta color" of his choice.
In his turn player rolls three dice and advance three of four pieces, each being moved in the number of spaces shown by one of the three dice.

If the first pawn arrivs in Finish a die is removed. 
If the second pawn arrives next to it a second die is removed.
If the third pawn arrives next to them the game is over.
If The finishing order of the pawns gives the so called "trifecta color" showed on card the player wins the game.

Publisher Blurb:

Welcome to Samaria... an abandoned planet, a ruined world, a place where few still remember! The world of Dark Age is a world of contradiction. Plasma rifles meet crossbows, laser torches meet horse-drawn ploughs, and future philosophy meets ancient religion. However, the inhabitants of Dark Age share one, simple trait: the instinct for survival at any cost!

Featuring art from the inimitable Brom and Dark Age's own in-house artists, the Dark Age: Apocalypse Core Rules contains everything you need to play Dark Age, a fully scaleable, skirmish-level wargame using 28-33mm scale miniatures. Within these pages you'll find rules for campaigns and scenarios, as well as information on terrain interaction and weather effects to liven up your game, plus 13 playable Forcelists, complete with fantastic artwork and intriguing storylines.

Re-implements:

    Dark Age: Core Rules

The "thief of stars" in English is a cooperative game where players play together against the mage.

The mage Fedor has stolen all the stars. Player must recover and hang these in the sky before he regains his powers.

In his turn player rolls the dice and advance the number of boxes. There are squares where the stars could be hanged or bad squares where player help the mage regain his power.

The game ends in two ways:
Either the players have hung all the stars in the sky and win.
or the mage Fedor has regains his power and the players lose the game.

Card game using a regular deck of cards and a board.

"The Board represents a typical year;  a constant struggle to pay endless bills with a fixed income and a few opportunities of supplementing it.  But with good management and more good luck than bad, it is just possible to get through the year with a few pounds saved!  The winner of the game is the first person who proves he can do so."

You start the year with 100 pounds, and every player starts on January 1st.

On your turn you may play a card of your choice that matches the suit on the square on the board that you are currently on. If you do, you move that many spaces equivalent to the card that you played (Jack = 11, Queen = 12, King =13). The square you now land on will dictate the suit you should play next turn so that you can advance again. Squares you land on will have good or bad instructions (Gain 6 pounds, lose 9 pounds for example), and so on.

You win the game if you have at least 100 pounds and a card that will take you to New Year's Eve.

A game for younger children.

On their turn, each player rolls a regular die. The number they roll indicates which part of their Beatrix Potter character card that they can 'assemble'. Unusually for these sort of games, like Beetle, is that you need nine parts to your character. Number 1 represents each corner piece so you will need to roll a 1 four times to assemble each corner of your picture.

The first to finish their Peter Rabbit character picture, wins.

Tactical board game where you have to shop as quickly as possible while managing its budget. Each player receives 12 euros and its shopping list. 
In her turn player roll the dice and moves her pawn in the direction of her choice. Every time she lands on a colored box she can make a purchase in the store of the same color. She then roll the dice to determine Euros she may use. The amount sets her budget and she decides whether to buy. The winner is the first that comes out of the market with all purchases in her shopping list!

Board of Dreams is a baseball boardgame simulation.

Board of Dreams is a game for 2 players.
You will be manager of yours team.
There are so many players to choose to form their lineup, the pitchers who get tired easily and the team must be balanced when it replaces.

Each launch is called from players, and hit the ball may not always be the best choice to make.

Each element of the team has its own characteristics, fields exalt one or other player.

One board, two teams, two dices and 9 innings do you want more?
Just manage your team, pitch the ball, hit a home runs and win the game.

A few simple rules to a great passion, baseball.

A hardback book featuring three games based on Greek mythology. The three sets are:

Tribes of Legend: This is a miniatures game involving armies of humans, centaurs and satyrs. Combat is dice-driven, movememtn is simple, and the basic grouping for all activities is the unit (as opposed to individual figures). Rules are provided for terrain effects, and each faction has its own special rules. The overall game rules are very simple, shunning the usual complexity of miniatures rules.

Ancient Heroes: a miniatures skirmish game for smaller battles. This is a playing card driven battle game, where individual figures move around the tabletop and draw cards to perform tasks and fight battles. Different fighting abilities and levels of armour are represented by differing card values in the game. Ordinary playing cards are used to play with.

Trials of a Demigod: a solitaire quest driven by action cards.This is mostly an exercise in pulling cards and seeing the total they add up to - nicely presented but not very much of a game.

The players have to draw a word that their teammates have to guess before time runs out. But that's not so easy, because 6 different categories representing more difficult. The painter must, depending on the category, draw the image upside down, paint standing with the "other" hand, humming, or standing on one leg etc.

Team who finish first the "winner's circle" wins the game!

Starmada is a miniatures board game of starship combat. At its most basic level, players take command of mighty fleets in a general attempt to reduce each other to just so much space junk. At its most advanced, the game can be customized to breathe life into any science fiction background that players might imagine.

The Nova Rulebook represents a new beginning for The Universal Game of Starship Combat. While in some ways this new edition is notably different from previous incarnations of the game, at its core Starmada remains the game players around the world have grown to know and love. As always, the guiding principle has been simple, but not simplistic. Within this book, players will find:

Streamlined inertial movement, with optional movement systems to encompass a wide range of settings;
An intuitive combat system, including three distinct and layered types of starship defenses; and
The most comprehensive set of starship construction rules available in any game currently available!

Dozens of stand-alone options and advanced rules are provided, from which you may pick and choose to fit your desired level of complexity and create the type of game YOU want to play.

Re-implements:

     Starmada X
     Starmada: The Admiralty Edition

Boneyard is a silent-bid auction game in which players are bidding on buckets of money. The object is to be the first player to accumulate 40 dollars.  Each player starts the game with 26 dollars.

This game is part of the Poker Suite compilation from CheapAss Games.

Seven-Handed Poker is a clever little way to play poker!  This game requires a single deck of playing cards and seven poker chips.

In Seven-Handed Poker, players play any amount of cards from their hands.  The player with the better poker hand wins the round. After each round, players always draw three cards regardless of how many cards they just played.  Hand sizes will grow and shrink depending on how many cards a player plays each round.

A fun and entertaining game well suited for social evenings. The game is about answering 10 questions in a fast pace without hesitation. Also, you may not answer yes or no, you may not cite the question, repeat an earlier answer or answer with a question. Be quick and guard your tongue! If you fail to abide by the aforementioned rules you fail and lose your turn. However, if you manage to answer all questions in a correct fashion you get to keep the question card. The players may agree upon how many cards are needed to win (and thus affect the playing time).

Alfapet Razzle is renewed and modern version of the classic word game Alfapet (also know as Scrabble). Create as many and as long words as you can in just one minute. The box includes a hourglass for keeping time and rules for three different versions of the game. Part of Alga's Qube series of games.

Alfapet Razzle on taas täällä – uudistettuna ja nykyaikaisena. Muodosta mahdollisimman monta ja pitkää sanaa yhden minuutin aikana. Kuutiossa on sisään rakennettu tiimalasi ajan ottamista varten. Pakkaus sisältää peliohjeet kolmeen hauskaan ja haastavaan pelivaihtoehtoon. Alfapet Razzle on Qube-perheen uusin jäsen. 2-6 pelaajalle, yli 10-vuotiaille Peliaika: Noin 30-60 minuuttia
As the title says, Charades with all the subjects being rude, the ruder the better. Obviously aimed at the older 'market'. The winner is the team who gets most correct.

An English football game but more linked to the business of football rather than playing football games.

The board has two tracks, the inner one for the first half of the game, where you build a team and a decent stadium to play in. Then, in the second half, you go round the outer track and hope to score as many goals as you can because goals are converted into cash.

Nice footballer playing pieces.

The most cash wins the game (which is sadly true in the 21st century British world of real football).

After a devastating nuclear war, six human factions are seeking shelter in the Centauri system. On the verge of extinction, the humans are saved by a superior civilization, allegedly the Centaurians, and each faction is given a fresh start on a new planet. Thus the exodus of humanity seems to have ended on the planets orbiting the star called Proxima Centauri. When the Centaurians announce their departure, the struggle for power commences once again.

In Exodus: Proxima Centauri, the six factions fight for dominance in an epic empire-building game, striving to build a new human empire on the ashes of the Centaurian civilization. Each player will build his own space fleet of customized ships and conquer new planets, fight the Centaurian Resistance and the other players, negotiate and vote for political decisions, research Centaurian technologies, and much more.

Exodus is a 4X game featuring a tech tree, blind bidding on political laws and resolutions, hidden movement, resource management, logistics, and engine building.  Exodus is a game that greatly encourages and rewards combat with NPCs and other players--both through ships and weapons of mass destruction.


     Interactive Setup for Exodus (nskn.net)

Humorous quiz game about Switzerland.
Goal of the game is to reach last station first. You can advance through luck of the dice, correct answers, real wealth, misleading other players and ignorance of the other players.
Players roll the dice and if arrow is rolled he moves up the ladder. If "K", "S" or "W" is rolled player takes a creative, estimate or knowledge card from the deck and asks a question. There is a short game and a team option.

In Blackrock City, you are the chief of your group of outlaws, and you want to claim as much gold and silver as possible by attacking cities and stagecoaches. You will have to be clever to estimate the number of outlaws needed to attack – and watch out for the Sheriff and your opponents!

The game is played in rounds. Each round, players bid on the right to perform the next bank robbery by placing a number of outlaws in the center of the playing area; each player starts with eight outlaws. Alternatively a player can skip the round or postpone an attack until after other players bid, but doing so will cause one or more of his outlaws to become wounded. When a player bids outlaws, the sheriff token moves a number of city tiles equal to the number of outlaws bid (in most cases). If a sheriff lands on a player's Chief of the Outlaws token – as these tokens are located on city tiles and not used for bidding – one of that player's outlaws is wounded.

The winner of the bid attacks a city, most likely netting him gold and possibly giving him new outlaws (as they are freed from that city's prison), but which city is attacked is determined by the difference between the winning bid and the lowest bid. Thus, bids from the other players will influence the winner's gains – and if the winner lands on the city tile where the sheriff is located, he gets nothing. The player with the second highest bid attacks the stagecoach and gains one silver.

If a player claims something from a city tile, it's flipped over and now has a different power for the remainder of the game, allowing a player who lands on the tile to steal gold or silver cubes from an opponent or wounding one of that player's outlaws. After each round, players collect the outlaws they used to bid and "wound" the healthy outlaws by flipping them over to their wounded side. A wounded outlaw who is wounded again is removed from the game. (Prisoners come into the game wounded, so they can be used only once.)

The game ends when no player has any outlaws remaining or all players refuse to bid in a given round. The player who has collected the most gold and silver wins!

The City-State of Tempest is a lively metropolis – some say the largest in the world – yet behind the city's cultured exterior, age-old cabals vie for power, fighting one another for dominance in a society ripe with political and economic turmoil. Led by shadowy figures who command a small cadre of loyal followers, these secret societies work in concert to seize the wealth and power of the fabled City-State of Tempest.

In Dominare, you are the puppet master of a conspiracy seeking to control Tempest. Agents are the key to Dominare. Use your agents to spread your influence through the city, building a network of hidden power to control the most valuable districts and blocks.

In the game, players first draft agents they want. Then, each turn, the players reveal one additional layer of their conspiracy. Each agent is a unique person in the City-State of Tempest, with unique abilities. The higher an agent in in your conspiracy, the more powerful that agent is.

Players spread their influence in key city blocks and districts, use agent and district abilities to further their plans, and manipulate the board to their benefit. Use your agents well, and influence and power will be yours. Use them poorly, and... well, you wouldn't be the first would-be ruler to vanish into the inky waters of the city canals....

Number 3 in the Tempest Shared World Game Series

The social elite of Tempest live in a world of power, intrigue, and alliances that can often shake the very foundations of the city's society. In Courtier, you move within these circles of social power to further your goals. Work with established courtiers to gain influence and stymie the rise of your rivals as you attempt to earn or cheat your way into their world.

In Courtier, 2–4 players compete for recognition in the royal court. Your mission is to act as an influence broker, manipulating the levers of power and granting favors to important supplicants. You accomplish this by influencing key people to act at your behest.

Play influence cards to gain sway over a key courtier, or play power cards to manipulate the board in your favor. Control each of the courtiers listed on a given petition, and you earn victory points for completing that request. Bonus points can be earned from cards and abilities. The winner is the player with the highest score at the end of the game.

Number 1 in the Tempest Shared World Game Series

War at Japan Sea is a strategic wargame for Russo-Japanese war. This game issued with Japanese self-published magazine SLGamer Volume 5.

Players control either Japanese Navy or Russian Navy. Players manage fleet movement and battle, to control of seas. The basic system of this game is reference from War at Sea.
The fall of Port Arthur fortress is a big event in the game. Russian Pacific fleet will be wiped out by fall of the fortress. Russian player can be delay the fall of the fortress by the control of the sea areas.

Winner will determine by victory points. Victory points can be earned from control of seas, and also earned from surviving warships at the end of the game.

The ancient prophecies announce the arrival of a child with amazing powers. The Haliwell sisters will need to eliminate the demons and prevent corruption of the chiled calledWyatt.

In her turn player rolls the dice and makes action accoridng to the squares she landed. There are different types of actions: Power, Demons, Allies, Places and Prophecies.

The game ends:
If demons reach the end of the Corruption track - the players lose the game.
The letters drawn by landing the Propecy squares form the word GIDEON - the players lose the game.
All demons are eliminated - the players win the game.

The marketplace ("tori" in Finnish, "torg" in Swedish) of Vaasa ("Vasa" in Swedish) was a vivid trade center in the 1930's, to which people from the surrounding countryside came to sell their goods. Townsfolk frequented the marketplace and various goods traded owners.

The war had its impact on the nation in the 1940's and there was shortage in food as well as other products, which lead to that the range of goods was reduced in stores as well as in the marketplace. Trade in the black market became usual especially when the ration cards were taken into use. The nation recovered in the 1950's and the belief in the future got the trade started once again.

In the game the players try to accomplish various tasks and bring goods from the market stands to the stores located around the marketplace at the same time as they are looking for the missing whistle of the marketplace guard.

During the game the players receive rewards for accomplished tasks, such as new skills, which allow them to move on to more difficult tasks. However, the life at the markeplace is not that easy. Good and bad crop years, the rising population, the war, economical success, the belief in the future and different events in the society have their impact on the prices and the players' possibilities to carry out tasks.

This is an exciting and educating game for 2-4 players, in which local history and the memories of the elderly townsfolk of Vaasa are interwoven into an innovative boardgame.

The board has two sides, one easier and one harder. The game is suitable for both young and more mature players.

Samurai Battles puts you in command of brave warriors clashing on the battlefields of feudal Japan! Assemble your army using magnificently detailed and historically accurate miniatures, then face your opponent on an endless variety of battlefields created from beautifully painted terrain and elevation tiles.

You can play Samurai Battles two different ways:


    Commands & Colors: Designed by Richard Borg, this award-winning game system features a fast-paced, card-driven mechanism to represent the "fog of war". Special Dragon cards, along with Honor and Fortune tokens, will influence your luck in the thick of the battle!



    Art of Tactic: Designed by Konstantin Krivenko, this game system requires wits and strategy. You and your opponent secretly plan your moves every turn, then the actions of your warriors are resolved simultaneously – just like a real battle!


Both game systems are easy to learn, and offer deep strategic and tactical challenges to please every fan of historical board games. Samurai Battles is the perfect blend of the beautiful and the historic – and the perfect way to explore the exciting battles of medieval Japan. So grab your katana and take up your naginata: Glory and honor await you in Samurai Battles!

Etsi ja löydä ("Seek and Find") is a game for children. There are 36 picture cards and 50 question cards in the game. The picture cards are placed on the table face up. Then a random question card is drawn (by a player who can read, otherwise the players do not necessarily have to know how to read yet) and a player tries to find quickly as possible one or more cards matching the question card. Usually the question relates to some detail in the picture cards (for example: find as many animals as possible with a tail!). The player marks the found cards with a piece and scores points as shown on a timer (a special timer included in the game). The player with the most points in the end wins.
